urn:contentItem:6GKM-5S73-RXN6-P1YK-00000-00Spain Activates Emergency Support for Wildfire-Affected Zones2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSpain Activates Emergency Support for Wildfire-Affected Zones

Link to Image

Link to Story

The Spanish government on Tuesday officially designated regions impacted by recent wildfires as catastrophe zones, unlocking access to urgent emergency relief.



Interior Minister Fernando Grande-Marlaska announced the decision during a press briefing aired on a national broadcaster, confirming the designation covers all areas affected by the 113 wildfires reported between June 23 and August 25.

"We are facing one of the worst environmental crises in recent years," Grande-Marlaska said, emphasizing that residents in these zones are now eligible to apply for compensation. The relief package also extends to communities struck by severe flooding at June's end.

Government support will target households, businesses, and local governments, alongside compensation for farmers who suffered losses in crops, forests, and livestock. The plan includes funding for infrastructure repairs and offers preferential loan options to aid recovery efforts.

According to the European Forest Fire Information Service, wildfires have burned roughly 418,000 hectares across Spain this summer, an area larger than the island of Mallorca. Nonetheless, Interior Minister Fernando Grande-Marlaska noted that it remains premature to provide a definitive evaluation of the overall damage.

Currently, 15 wildfires remain active in northwest Spain, predominantly in Zamora and Ourense provinces. Despite recent drops in temperature, firefighting operations continue to face challenges due to persistent strong winds.

urn:contentItem:6H2F-3FD3-S123-82HR-00000-00SORRY, SMOKEY2025-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisMAGAZINEPg. G-1SORRY, SMOKEYCONTROLLED BURNS ARE ALL THE RAGE TO FIGHT WILDFIRES AND INVASIVESMary Ann Thomas Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

Checking the wind direction, a certified contractor from West Virginia commenced the second controlled burn at the Pittsburgh Botanic Garden in mid-October to eradicate and slow the growth of a stubborn invasive plant - lespedeza, also known as Chinese bushclover.

Controlled burns, a practice among Native Americans for centuries, are becoming more common to stop the spread of invasive plants, prevent larger wildfires and keep meadows and other habitats from becoming overgrown.

The 460-acre Pittsburgh Botanic Garden in Collier and North Fayette held its first-ever prescribed burn on Oct. 15 as part of continuing efforts to eradicate Chinese bushclover.

Growing 3 feet or higher in large, dense stands, the plant outcompetes native species. A single plant can potentially produce more than 1,000 seeds.

"The large dense stands of lespedeza become seed reservoirs," said Sue Myers, horticulture and conservation director for the Pittsburgh Botanic Garden.

The plant was likely introduced to the site, a former coal mine, many years ago.

Staffers first noticed it in 2022 on the site, but not in the garden. Then last year, Chinese bushclover was found in two garden areas.

"The burn was an important and necessary experiment using a traditional land management practice that the garden had not used before," Myers said.

The controlled burn is only one tool to control lespedeza; they also use mowing (timed before seed set), animal grazing and natural and conventional herbicides, she said.

"As we follow an ecological landscaping approach at the garden, all of the methods that are traditional/cultural and less toxic were our first choices," Myers said.

The botanic garden hoped to completely burn 8 acres in the Exhibit Garden and the Margaret Lawrence Simon Dogwood Meadow.

"The actual burn pattern was a 'mosaic' of fire effects, with some areas burning completely while in other areas only the fine fuels burned in the garden's meadows. This was the lower grasses and thatch, leaving the standing vegetation scorched but standing," she said.

With unexpected dew in the morning and changing winds in the afternoon, the weather contributed to the burn pattern, she said.

Ecological landscaping

Ecological landscaping considers the ecology of a site and enhances the benefits to humans and other organisms by building healthy soils, selecting the proper plants, planting correctly, using non-toxic pest control, conserving water and mimicking natural systems, Myers said.

The Pittsburgh Botanic Garden contracted with Nature Works LLC, of Shepherdstown, W.Va., which has been carefully setting prescribed burns for more than 20 years.

"Smokey the Bear had it wrong," said James Remuzzi, CEO of the company, noting that his firm receives more requests each year for the controlled fires.

Remuzzi assembled a team of nearly a dozen fire technicians with the tools of the trade - rogue hoes and rakes. They ignited the fire with drip torches and controlled it with "fuel breaks" - areas without vegetation to burn.

Certified firefighters employ a range of techniques to control a fire, which is simultaneously governed by the wind and topography. The goal is to safely burn an area between marked boundaries. The logistics of starting and moving a fire is to contain the blaze and get ahead of it.

Oct. 15 turned out to be a particularly breezy day. Remuzzi warned his team that the direction of the wind could change, and it did.

"Keep an eye on where the smoke is blowing," he said.

Situational awareness is a constant for controlled burns.

More controlled fires

In the early 1900s, dousing forest fires became organized as blazes broke out along railroads, said Todd Breininger, the prescribed fire specialist for the state Department of Conservation and Natural Resources.

In fact, the state's Bureau of Forestry was founded to deal with wildfires, he said.

Smokey Bear, the national forest fire prevention icon, was created in the early 1900s and ignited an era of fire suppression targeting people who unwittingly started wildfires.

"But people came to realize that fires are a good tool to manage the landscape and it's cheaper than using herbicides," Breininger said.

"There's a lot more interest than years ago and now the trend is increasing for more controlled burns."

The Nature Conservancy, a national environmental nonprofit based in ArlingtonVa., has been using prescribed burns for more than 60 years with success.

Prescribed fires can blunt wildfire severity up to 62% by decimating combustibles like leaf litter and dead branches, the nonprofit reports.

Additionally, controlled fires promote the growth of natural grasslands and mature forests by suppressing invasive plants and undesirable woody shrubs.

"Soon after our highly trained crews set fire to the land, the burned landscapes respond with a flush of native plants that attract birds, pollinators and other wildlife," according to the nonprofit's website.

A bonus is the reduction in tick populations because the fire burns leaf litter where the insects live.

Pennsylvania agencies have long known the benefits of controlled burns â€“ eliminating fuel for major wildfires, controlling invasive species, restoring native plants and promoting the growth of young trees.

State legislation passed in 2009 encourages safe and more controlled burns. All burn plans must be approved by DCNR with certified firefighters doing the work.

From 2010 to 2022, controlled burns increased dramatically from 56 to 441 fires. Acreage burned has also skyrocketed.

In the last few years, the number of controlled burns has plateaued at about 15,000 acres across Pennsylvania, Breininger said.

"The reason we didn't burn more acres is that some of our weather windows weren't there - it's been too dry and too dangerous because of droughts," he said.

In Pennsylvania, the main driver for a controlled burn is habitat management by the Pennsylvania Game Commission and DCNR.

"We're trying to get rid of woody plants and invasive species by knocking them down in favor of seasonal grasses and preserving field and meadow habitat," Breininger said.

For the state's Bureau of Forestry, controlled burns are used to promote forest regeneration, particularly better growing conditions for oak species, he said.

There are some prescribed burns in state forests to reduce the buildup of vegetation and prevent larger wildfires, which do occur but not at the scale in the western part of the country.

Future plans at the Pittsburgh Botanic Garden include more work controlling woody plants in the meadow and monitoring for new lespedeza growth early next spring. Myers plans to use more controlled burns in the future.

urn:contentItem:6GKN-F8K3-RRV7-3025-00000-00Foran Mining Maintained at Buy at Stifel Canada as McIlvenna Bay 50% Complete; Price Target Kept at C$4.752025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisForan Mining Maintained at Buy at Stifel Canada as McIlvenna Bay 50% Complete; Price Target Kept at C$4.75

Stifel Canada on Wednesday maintained its buy rating on the shares of Foran Mining (FOM.TO) and its C$4.75 price target after the company reported on the progress of construction for its McIlvenna Bay project in Saskatchewan.

"Impact: Slight Positive (neutral to formal valuation). FOM has released a monthly construction update for July. McIlvenna Bay has surpassed the 50% completion mark with 8% monthly completion in July, inflecting upwards from 5% in June due to forest fire delays. Surface construction continues to shift focus to installation from larger earthworks/steel/concrete work, positive for costing risk as i) these items had largely driven the May costing update and ii) with detailed engineering at 98% end of July, we think a shift to installation focus allows avenues of progress to increase into the weather-challenging winter season. While the market may be hesitant to pay for construction updates, we note a growing asymmetry in FOM shares, where at 50% completion average developer out-performance has been ~34.2% versus FOM under-performing by 29.1% since the start of construction," analyst Cole McGill wrote.

(MT Newswires covers equity, commodity and economic research from major banks and research firms in North America, Asia and Europe. Research providers may contact us here: https://www.mtnewswires.com/contact-us)

Price: 2.97, Change: -0.08, Percent Change: -2.62

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RH73-S7KW-C1T4-00000-00ICE Arrests Mexican Firefighters Putting Out a Fire2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisICE Arrests Mexican Firefighters Putting Out a Fire


Mexico City -Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents detained for more than three hours members of two contractor brigades that were participating in the fight against the Bear Gulch Fire, considered the largest wildfire in Washington. The operation occurred near Lake Cushman, on the Olympic Peninsula, according to reports from the Seattle Times and the AP.


During the intervention, the agents demanded identification from the firefighters and detected two people in irregular immigration status, one of them with a previous deportation order. Both were transferred to detention centers in the state.
Following the arrests, the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) decided to terminate the contracts with Table Rock Forestry Inc. and ASI Arden Solutions Inc. and to remove the remaining 42 workers from federal lands.
The Bear Gulch Fire remains active as of July 6, 2025, with more than 9,000 acres consumed and barely 13% control. Although the Incident Management Team assured that the arrest did not disrupt operations, the event generated widespread political backlash.
Senator Patty Murray called the action "immoral and dangerous," while Governor Bob Ferguson warned about the impact these measures could have on disaster response capacity. Senator Ron Wyden, from Oregon, denounced that one of those arrested had applied for a U-Visa after collaborating with authorities in another investigation.
Civil organizations and forest fire experts warned that this type of operation could discourage the participation of private contractors, who represent a key resource to reinforce emergency bodies in critical situations.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y623-RS92-21R4-00000-00Mega-operation in Lima, Arequipa and Tumbes dismantles Desa II criminal organization (VIDEO AND PHOTOS)2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisMega-operation in Lima, Arequipa and Tumbes dismantles Desa II criminal organization (VIDEO AND PHOTOS)


A simultaneous operation carried out in Lima, Arequipa and Tumbes led to the dismantling of the criminal organization Desa II, linked to crimes of extortion and alleged contract killings.
This was informed by the Minister of the Interior, Carlos Malaver, who highlighted that the intervention took place in the early hours of Tuesday, September 9.


The police action counted with the participation of 600 agents of the National Police and allowed the raid of 32 properties, among them a pavilion of the Huacho prison. As a result, 24 people were arrested, mostly Venezuelan nationals, including the alleged leader of the organization.
"This subject would have come to reorganize the structure after the fall of Desa 1. Criminal behavior is dynamic, but the State responds firmly," said Malaver.
During the operation, vehicles, technological equipment, explosives, cell phones and various documents were seized.
Likewise, with the support of the Financial Intelligence Unit, 50 bank accounts were frozen and the movement of approximately 20 million soles was blocked.
According to the investigations, the money originated in seven front companies that used the "smurfing" modality to transfer funds to Ecuador and Colombia, with final destination in Venezuela.
The Minister urged citizens who have been victims of extortion to file their complaints. "Thanks to this coup we are going to clarify several bloody facts. We need the victims to collaborate by approaching the police stations or by calling the 111 line", he emphasized.
The intervention was carried out by the Criminal Investigation Department with the participation of the Public Prosecutor's Office. The authorities specified that the proceedings will continue in order to determine the level of involvement of inmates of Huacho prison and to completely dismantle the financial and operational structure of Desa II.

urn:contentItem:6FKY-JNW3-S9F6-73CV-00000-00New Jersey Forest Fire Service crews battle wildfire in Vineland2025-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisNew Jersey Forest Fire Service crews battle wildfire in VinelandBy Jessica MacAulay(KYW)

Click here for updates on this story

VINELAND, New Jersey (KYW) -- Firefighters are working to extinguish a wildfire still burning in Vineland, New Jersey on Saturday.

The New Jersey Forest Fire Service said the wildfire burning in the Peaslee Wildlife Management Area in Cumberland County was spotted by the Belleplain Fire Tower just before 12:30 p.m. Friday. As of 10 a.m. Saturday, the fire has burned 1,000 acres and is 50% contained.

Union Road is closed between Route 49 and Mays Landing Road, and Bennett's Mill Road is closed between Union Road and Manumuskin River. According to the NJFFS, no structures are currently threatened by the wildfire's blaze.

Chopper 3 was over the Peaslee Wildlife Management Area Friday afternoon, where thick clouds of smoke billowed and flames continued to build.

NJFFS officials said fire engines, bulldozers and ground crews are all working on the firefight.

The NJFFS also has a helicopter capable of dropping 300 gallons of water, as well as a contact air tanker, which can drop 600 gallons of water, that have been deployed to battle the blaze.

The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

urn:contentItem:6GK0-T023-RRRB-300D-00000-00German firefighters helping to control Spain wildfires2025-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisGerman firefighters helping to control Spain wildfiresMadrid (dpa) -

German firefighters helping to tackle the wildfires ravaging much of Spain have been redeployed to the northern Castile and León region after a successful deployment further south, Spanish media reported on Sunday.

The Spanish authorities have despatched them to La Baña, a village north of the Portuguese border, where the flames have been approaching. Some 330 residents have already been evacuated, according to a report in the Leonoticias newspaper.

Public broadcaster TV-Sender RTVE has reported that 14 fires are still burning countrywide.

Previously, 67 German firefighters along with 21 vehicles had been battling fires in Jarilla in Extremadura to the south. Spanish police published a video showing them in Puebla de Sanabria on the way to La Baña.

The situation has eased to some extent, according to the authorities, partly as a result of an end to an extreme heatwave with temperatures soaring well above 40 degrees Celsius.

The current situation is worst in the north-west, where the German firefighters will help their Spanish counterparts until Tuesday.

This month, Spain and Portugal have experienced the worst wildfires in years, with at least eight people dying. According to initial estimates from the European Forest Fire Information System, around 6,840 hectares have been destroyed.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y603-RS3T-S306-00000-00San Juan de Miraflores: Mutilated body found inside a suitcase in industrial zone2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSan Juan de Miraflores: Mutilated body found inside a suitcase in industrial zone


The body of a man, approximately 35 years old, was found mutilated inside an abandoned suitcase on Las Torres street, in an industrial zone of San Juan de Miraflores.
According to police information, the discovery occurred around eight o'clock in the morning, when a recycler came across the suitcase and, upon opening it, discovered a human arm.


The worker immediately alerted the authorities, who confirmed that inside was a raffia bag with more remains, reported América Noticias.
Initial examinations revealed that the victim had multiple mutilations. The left arm was severed and there were also cuts at the wrist. In addition, the body was missing the lower limbs, which leads to the presumption that other bags with more body parts could be found in the area.
So far, the man's identity has not been established. The police indicated that he was about 35 years old and that fingerprints are being analyzed, in addition to reviewing records from security cameras in the vicinity to obtain clues to advance the investigation.
Neighbors of the sector indicated that the suitcase was not in the place the day before, so it is presumed that it was left in the early hours of the morning. The area where the discovery took place is a wasteland, surrounded by factories and Sedapal treatment plants, with no nearby houses.
Criminalistics agents arrived at the site to collect evidence and cordoned off the perimeter to preserve the scene. The main hypothesis is that the crime is linked to criminal gangs, although the authorities do not rule out other lines of investigation.
They also confirmed that they will analyze the images captured by a nearby security camera, which could have recorded the moment when the suitcase was abandoned.

urn:contentItem:6GR4-8F93-RRV9-Y14W-00000-00Golfers endure scorching heat at Hope tournament2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSPORTSPg. 9Golfers endure scorching heat at Hope tournamentErnestine Franson

In spite of intense heat and smoke from the Yale-area forest fire, 38 players from Hope, the Lower Mainland and the Okanagan enjoyed two days of golf and social activities sponsored by the Ladies’ Club of the Hope Golf Course.

Golf partners played a scramble on Saturday, Aug. 23 and a scotch ball on Sunday, Aug. 24. In order to encourage new players, a new division requiring no handicap was added this year for the first day of play. Players with a handicap played on both days.

Practice rounds on Friday and appetizers in the evening were followed by a putting contest won by Tracy Macfarlane sinking a long putt. Second place went to Sharyn Harvey.

Minjeong Kim and Jennifer Eum, both of Langley, captured Overall Low Gross for the second year in a row with a score of 144.

Overall Low Net , with a score of 125, was won by Hope locals Diane Field and Shelley Simpson.

Other Hope winners included Tracy Macfarlane, 2nd Low Gross; Pam Testawich and Virginia White, 1st Low Net; Tammy Shields and June Lowe, 2nd Low Net; Anna Johnstad-Moeller and Pam Smith, 1st Low Gross; Inge Wilson and Deb Dixon, 1st Low Net;

and Jessica McWilliams, 2nd Low Net.

Back by popular demand, the duo Room to Dance from West Kelowna provided toe-tapping music that got everyone up and dancing after a full-course buffet on Saturday evening.

Tournament coordinator Macfarlane made a point of honouring several people in her address to the players, including past coordinator Keren Hasell who spearheaded the event for several very successful years. She also recalled two very active and dearly missed members of the Hope Ladies’ Club, Alice Woods and Tama Kawase, both of whom passed away this year.

Fay Stewart continued the tradition of providing several amusing floral touches around the course.

The tournament would not have been possible without the help of over 30 sponsors as well as the many volunteers who made sure the tournament ran smoothly.

Largely due to unflagging work and support from multiple volunteers, the course has come a long way in recovering from a devastating flood in 2021. Great work from greenskeeper Mike Carrier and his crew continue to bring the course up to its full potential.

The Hope Ladies Golf Club always welcomes new players to join.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S8K3-RXVG-24GD-00000-00Bolivia faces five 'active fires' and 391 heat sources2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisBolivia faces five 'active fires' and 391 heat sources


While the teams continue their deployment, the country reached 391 hot spots on Monday. The Government's inter-institutional monitoring also reflects that five "active fires" have been officially registered this day.


"We have five 'active fires'. All are in the department of Santa Cruz," explained the departmental director of the National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology (Senamhi) Santa Cruz, Omar Soliz.
These "active fires" occurred punctually in the municipalities of Ascensión de Guarayos (1), Concepción (2), Carmen Ribero Tórrez (1) and San Ignacio de Velasco (1). Santa Cruz is also the department most affected by hot spots.
HEAT SPOTS
"At the moment we have 391 hot spots, this is information updated at nine o'clock in the morning today, September 15. Santa Cruz has the largest share with 189 hot spots; it is followed with another higher incidence by the department of Beni with 186," said Soliz.
In addition, Pando reports eight hot spots; La Paz, five; Cochabamba, one; and Tarija also has one, according to the report.
As well as immediate attention, the Government has committed to constant monitoring for the timely response to forest fires in the country. In this sense, these daily reports are made, which give signals of a persistence of fire risk in the national territory.
The director of Senamhi Santa Cruz indicated that currently, regarding the risk of spreading forest fires, there are 18 municipalities in red alert, all corresponding to the department of Santa Cruz.
Another 77 municipalities are in orange alert. Of this total, 20 are registered in Santa Cruz; 18 in Beni; 15 in Pando; 15 in Chuquisaca; three in Tarija; five in Cochabamba and one in the department of La Paz.
"This according to the reports issued by Senamhi and the Forest Fire Monitoring Information System," said Soliz.
He also recalled that until Monday was in force an orange alert for rising temperatures in 40 municipalities of Santa Cruz, 19 of Beni, 15 of Pando and two of La Paz.
In this way, the national monitoring continues in this dry season, which means for Bolivia a high vulnerability to fires year after year. This year, according to the Government, the impact is so far less than in 2024, however, the national emergency has been activated and Armed Forces personnel continue to be deployed to attend the outbreaks that still generate concern and risk.

urn:contentItem:6GKW-3FJ3-RRJ0-T4V8-00000-00Exiled outlet says Ukrainian drones cause fire just 10km from 'Putin's palace'2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisExiled outlet says Ukrainian drones cause fire just 10km from 'Putin's palace'

By BBC Monitoring

A Ukrainian drone attack has caused a forest fire 10km away from a palace said to be linked to Russian President Vladimir Putin, exiled investigative outlet Agentstvo reported on 28 August. 

The palace is located near the town of Gelendzhik on the Black Sea coast and is reported to be the private residence of Putin, according to a 2021 investigation by the late opposition leader Alexei Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation (FBK).

The fall of drone "debris" on the night of 27-28 August had led to the spread of three fires in the forest near the village of Krinitsa in Gelendzhik, Agentstvo said, citing the operational headquarters of Krasnodar Territory.

"This village is located just 10km as the crow flies from the palace of Vladimir Putin on Cape Idokopas," Agentstvo wrote.

It also cited reports published by state news agency TASS, saying that the area engulfed by fire had increased from 7,000 sq metres to 32,000 sq metres. 

The Proyekt (Proekt) investigative website previously claimed that Putin had been avoiding travelling to the southern city of Sochi in Russia's Krasnodar Territory because of security concerns. 

Last month, Russian media said that a mass drone attack on Sochi had killed two people.

See also: Briefing: Putin said taking extra travel precautions amid security fears

Source: Agentstvo in Russian 0730 GMT 28 Aug 25

urn:contentItem:6GMH-DG33-RRTW-P09P-00000-00Safety warning for firewood collectors as forests set to open up in spring2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisNews5Safety warning for firewood collectors as forests set to open up in springMichelle Smith

Spring firewood collection period runs September 1 to November 30

Firewood collectors have been reminded to stick to the rules and prioritise safety as firewood collection areas open today.

Members of the public can collect firewood for use at home from designated collection areas in state forests and some forest parks, but daily limits and maximum household limits apply.

Collectors can take two cubic metres per person per day to a maximum of 16 cubic metres per household per financial year.

Outside of the two designated firewood collection periods each year, which run from September 1 to November 30, and March 1 to June 30, it is illegal to collect any firewood from public land.

On August 5, Conservation Regulator Forest and Wildlife Officers and police intercepted two people who were allegedly removing firewood from the Glen Park State Forest, north of Ballarat, seizing a trailer loaded with firewood and block splitters.

"Most people do the right thing, collect wood that is already on the ground, take only what they need and stick to limits and rules," said Forest Fire Management Victoria deputy chief fire officer Michael Condon.

He urged people to check the weather and conditions before heading out to collect wood, and take care when using chainsaws and other equipment.

Maps for the spring firewood collection season will be online on September 1.

Mr Condon urged people to get their wood now, ready for next winter.

"Depending on the species and level of dryness when cut, most wood takes longer than 12 months to dry," he said.

"Ideally people should plan their firewood needs two years in advance."

Domestic firewood collection in state forests and parks will run from September 1 to November 30. Picture by Michelle Smith

urn:contentItem:6GHB-61C3-RRJS-24SY-00000-00Deadly Wildfires Engulf Europe, Killing at Least Four2025-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisDeadly Wildfires Engulf Europe, Killing at Least FourMandy Taheri

The fires come amid record-high temperatures in the region, with dry landscapes and materials further fueling fires from Greece to Portugal.

Dozens of wildfires raging across southern Europe, fueled by high temperatures, droughts, and dry fuels, have killed at least three people in Spain and one in Portugal.

Newsweek has reached out to Portugal's National Emergency and Civil Protection Authority and the European Forest Fire Information System for comment via email on Saturday.

Why It Matters

The fires come amid record-high temperatures in the region, with dry landscapes and materials further fueling fires from Greece to Portugal, marking one of the region's worst fire seasons on record. The European Union (EU) has sent firefighting planes to help battle the blazes, with five countries having requested assistance.

Thousands of people have been forced to evacuate from their homes across the region, and around 100 have been injured across countries.

What To Know

Spain has been hit particularly hard, with more than 14 major fires, General Director of Emergency Services Virginia Barcones told the Associated Press. Wildfires have disrupted mass transit, forcing highway closures and suspending high-speed rail service. So far this year, more than 390,000 acres have burned in the country, according to the European Forest Fire Information System.

Earlier this week, Spain confirmed a third death from the wildfires, a volunteer firefighter who sustained severe burns. Spain has arrested several people on suspicion of arson.

In neighboring Portugal, nearly 4,000 firefighters have battled at least seven major blazes, according to the AP. The country is currently under a state of alert until late Sunday night.

The former mayor of Vila Franca do Deão, Carlos Damaso, "was killed in a fire he was fighting in his parish," Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, the president of Portugal, wrote in Portuguese in a press release Friday.

What People Are Saying

AccuWeather wrote in an August 14 X post: "Europe is facing its worst wildfire season on record as deadly wildfires rage across France, Spain, Portugal, Greece, and Albania. More than 2.4 million acres have burned across Europe."

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez wrote in a Saturday X post: "All my encouragement and strength to the four injured members of @UMEgob in the Yeres fire, in León, and to their families. I thank them for their effort and dedication and hope they recover soon."

The Spanish State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) wrote in a Friday X post: "This Friday, very high or extreme fire danger in most of the country. The danger will remain at very high or extreme levels during the weekend and Monday, days when the heatwave affecting us since the beginning of the month continues."

The United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction wrote in an X post: "Europe is experiencing a devastating wildfire season – wreaking havoc on landscapes, cities, and communities."

What Happens Next?

High temperatures are expected to continue throughout the weekend into Monday.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-0423-RTWF-73TC-00000-00Sanchez bets on acting "on a forest scale, not on a personal scale" to fight fires: "Let's not ideologize this matter".2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSanchez bets on acting "on a forest scale, not on a personal scale" to fight fires: "Let's not ideologize this matter".


The President of the Government, Pedro Sánchez, has opted to act "on a forest scale, not on a personal, individual, human or even political scale" to combat forest fires.


"We have to ask all of us, politicians, institutions, companies, workers, not to ideologize this matter," said Sánchez on Monday at the closing of the Economic Forum for Decarbonization.
At the event, he recalled that a week ago the Government presented its State Pact to face the climate emergency, "a great agreement open to all institutions, to all companies, also to workers' representatives, to political parties, to science, to the academic world, to society as a whole, including companies".
Likewise, he said that last Thursday, during his visit to some facilities of the forest fire reinforcement brigade in León, he spoke with "many brigadistas who had been directly fighting the fire".
One of them, according to Sánchez, told him that they should act "from the agreement". "We need to act thinking in terms of legislatures, in decades, because forests are treated, regenerated, rebuilt or grow precisely after decades, not every four years," he said.
"That is why I was talking about the forest scale and not the human scale or the political scale. That is why it is so essential to promote this State Pact, a long-range forest policy, with a long vision, to face the challenges that we already have in the present and that will unfortunately increase as a consequence of the increase in temperatures", he warned.
The President of the Government insisted that what the brigadier who "was directly fighting the fires during this summer's fires was telling him was not a simple opinion, it is pure common sense, pure knowledge based on science and reason".
"And I believe that this act shares this identical philosophy, because it expresses a long view, a far-reaching vision in the face of the greatest challenge facing humanity and, therefore, our country. A challenge that is existential," he stressed.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-KYV3-RWGD-N2V0-00000-00Firefighter killed in Portugal fighting fires2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisFirefighter killed in Portugal fighting fires


A firefighter died in Portugal as a result of injuries suffered in the fight against forest fires affecting the country, lamented Saturday the presidency, on the fourth deceased by the flames this summer.


In a statement, the presidency of Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa conveyed its condolences to the family of the firefighter "who tragically lost his life after directly fighting forest fires in the municipality of Sabugal," in the northern half of the country. According to Portuguese media, the firefighter was 45 years old and worked for a private firefighting company.
Portugal, like neighboring Spain, where four people have also died, is fighting several forest fires that have consumed some 60,000 hectares, despite a drop in temperatures that has improved the situation, according to Civil Protection.
According to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), about 278,000 hectares of land have burned since the beginning of the year in Portugal.
In 2017, more than 563,000 hectares were burned in fires that resulted in 119 deaths.
The Iberian Peninsula is heavily affected by climate change, which causes heat waves and longer droughts, drying out vegetation and favoring forest fires, according to experts.

urn:contentItem:6FJX-3RX3-RS64-T4PK-00000-00National Institute of Ecology Researchers Report Research in Ecology (Changes in Landcover and Biota due to 2019 Goseong Forest Fire)2025-04-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisECOLOGYNational Institute of Ecology Researchers Report Research in Ecology (Changes in Landcover and Biota due to 2019 Goseong Forest Fire)


2025 APR 14 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Data detailed on ecology have been presented. According to news originating from the National Institute of Ecology by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "This study investigates the impact of a large-scale forest fire that occurred in Wonamri, Toseong-myeon, Goseong-gun, South Korea, in 2019, by analyzing changes in biodiversity before and after the fire."


Financial supporters for this research include National Institute of Ecology; Ministry of Environment.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from National Institute of Ecology: "Using Sentinel-2 satellite imagery, the study quantitatively assesses the severity of the forest fire and changes in landcover, including reductions in forested areas and expansions of grasslands. The findings reveal a significant decrease in forest area and a substantial increase in grasslands within the affected region compared to unburned areas. The study also observes the influx of new species, including endangered ones. For instance, the number of bird species increased from one to three, and mammal species rose from three to six. However, amphibian and reptile populations declined, dropping from 15 to eight species in the burned area, indicating species-specific responses to the forest fire's impacts."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This research emphasizes the importance of understanding how forest fires differently affect various species and highlights the need for further studies to monitor biodiversity recovery and the long-term ecological consequences of forest fires."
For more information on this research see: Changes in Landcover and Biota due to 2019 Goseong Forest Fire. Geo Data, 2024,6(4):420-429. The publisher for Geo Data is GeoAI Data Society.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.22761/GD.2024.0038.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Gumsung Cheon, Researcher, Ecosystem Services Team, National Institute of Ecology, 1210 Geumgang-ro, Maseo-myeon, Seocheon-gun, 33657 Chungcheongnam-do, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include Heejin Moon, Jinhee Kim.
Keywords for this news article include: National Institute of Ecology, Biodiversity, Ecology.

urn:contentItem:6GM3-DTX3-RW6K-W2DW-00000-00Croatian Air Force tackles nearly 70 wildfires at home, aids abroad2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisCroatian Air Force tackles nearly 70 wildfires at home, aids abroad

Croatian firefighting aircraft have been deployed to 69 wildfires across the Adriatic coast since mid-June and also assisted in neighbouring countries and Israel, the defence ministry said on August 25.

The Adriatic region is regularly hit by wildfires during the summer months, often fuelled by high winds and prolonged dry spells. Across the European Union, this summer is the most severe wildfire season since records began, with more than 1.01mn hectares of land scorched so far, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

Between June 16 and August 25, firefighting squadrons were called out to blazes in several coastal counties, including 23 in Split-Dalmatia, 19 in Zadar and 17 in Sibenik-Knin, the ministry said in a statement. Crews also flew 52 reconnaissance missions to monitor high-risk areas.

In total, Croatian Air Force planes logged nearly 3,000 flights and more than 525 flight hours during the interventions, releasing more than 14,000 tonnes of water and 12,800 litres of foam.

Croatian aircraft were also dispatched eight times abroad this year to assist in firefighting operations in Israel, Albania, Bosnia & Herzegovina and, most recently, Montenegro.

Colonel Darko Kucej, commander of the 855th Firefighting Squadron, said pilots and technicians had already surpassed 500 flight hours this season, working in "extremely demanding conditions".

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-3DY3-RS5H-328C-00000-00Machu Picchu: local buses to replace Consettur after end of concession of the route to the citadel2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisMachu Picchu: local buses to replace Consettur after end of concession of the route to the citadel


The concession granted to the company Consettur for tourist transport on the Hiram Bingham route to the citadel of Machu Picchu came to an end this September 4. In view of this, local private companies authorized by the Municipality of Urubamba will temporarily take over the tourist transportation service, according to the regional governor of Cusco, Werner Salcedo Alvarez.


The measure seeks to guarantee the continuity of transportation from Machu Picchu Pueblo to the Inca citadel and vice versa, while a new bidding process is being carried out.
LEE: Forest fire in Machu Picchu was controlled after two days of hard work by brigaders
However, private sector tourism associations warn that doubts persist regarding the bus fleet and infrastructure, which continue to be in the hands of the companies that make up Consettur. This has fueled speculation about the possibility of these companies continuing to operate under the contingency scheme.
Protests in Urubamba
The transition has generated social tension. In the Main Square of Urubamba, a protest of Machupicchu Pueblo residents resulted in an altercation with neighbors of the province who rejected the mobilization. The protesters defended their struggle as a measure to protect tourism and questioned the mayor of Urubamba for not promoting the new bidding for the route in time.
The private tourism sector expressed its concern for the uncertainty generated by the end of the contract with Consettur. Guilds warned about possible risks to the safety of visitors, the impact on the reputation of the destination and the validity of tickets already purchased. They demand urgent measures to guarantee sufficient capacity and continuity of service to the world wonder.
At the same time, Congresswoman Ruth Luque Ibarra presented Bill No. 12294/2025-CR, which proposes to declare of national interest and public necessity the recovery of the Hiram Bingham route and its direct administration by the district municipalities of the province of Urubamba.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-H0D3-S01C-T16H-00000-00Korea shares forest disaster response know-how with Congo delegation 2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisKorea shares forest disaster response know-how with Congo delegation

The Korea Forest Service said Thurday that it has been hosting a two-week invitational training program for a 12-member Congolese delegation, running from Aug. 25 to Sept. 5.

The delegation, led by Toirambe Bamoninga Benjamin, secretary-general of Congo's Ministry of the Environment and Sustainable Development, features government officials, civil society representatives and academics.

The program is part of the "Integrated Climate Change Response Project through Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation Plus (REDD+) in Haut-Uele Province, the Democratic Republic of Congo," jointly implemented by the United Nations Development Program and the Korea International Cooperation Agency under an agreement between the Asian Forest Cooperation Organization and UNDP.

During their visit to KFS headquarters on Thursday, the delegation was briefed on Korea's reforestation success after the Korean War and its advanced forest disaster response system.

The agency also shared its overseas REDD+ projects contributing to Nationally Determined Contribution goals, while discussing ways to strengthen global forestry cooperation.

At the Forest Disaster Control Center, the group observed the Forest Fire Situation Control System and firefighting helicopter operations, along with the 24/7 disaster response system for fires, landslides and pest outbreaks.

They also visited the AFoCO Secretariat, the National Institute of Forest Science, the Korea National Arboretum and the Central Regional Office of the Forest Service, where they were introduced to predictive modeling, ICT-based command systems and smart forestry technologies such as thermal imaging cameras.

"The advanced monitoring systems using AI-based ICT platforms and the command system for immediate response were highly impressive," said Toirambe. "Korea's experience will serve as an invaluable reference in strengthening our disaster response capacity."

"With forest disasters worsening due to climate change, international cooperation is essential," added KFS Deputy Minister Lee Mira. "The KFS will continue to deepen cooperation with the Democratic Republic of Congo and jointly address climate change."

By Lee Kwon-hyung (kwonhl@heraldcorp.com)

Chung Hye-lim (hyelimchung@heraldcorp.com)

urn:contentItem:6H03-XPV3-S378-Y4BX-00000-00Briefly Noted2025-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisBOOKSPg. 79Briefly NotedLeo Lasdun

Breakneck, by Dan Wang (Norton). In recent decades, as China has laid down vast networks of high-speed rail and thrown up shimmering cities, Americans have developed a deepening sense that their own country struggles to get things done. In this ambitious account, Wang, a technology analyst with a journalist's eye for color, uses studies of Chinese innovation to show how the two countries' diverging paths and pathologies can be traced to their political cultures. Chinese leaders tend to be engineers who are capable of grand projects but liable to run roughshod over individual rights. The U.S., on the other hand, has become a society of lawyers, better at miring public infrastructure in proceduralism than at creating it. China's example can remind Americans to treasure their country's pluralism, Wang suggests, while also teaching them something about how to build.

Threads of Empire, by Dorothy Armstrong (St. Martin's). Carpets are "some of the world's greatest symbols of authority and control," Armstrong, a scholar of material culture, argues in this vivid history. She makes her case through profiles of twelve noteworthy specimens, including one frozen in the tomb of a Scythian chieftain; one photographed under the feet of Churchill, Stalin, and Roosevelt at the Yalta Conference, in 1945; and one crafted into a coat for a feudal Japanese warlord. The stories are fraught with violence and colonialism: Persian rugs, for instance, gained their glittering reputation in part from Victorian-era racial hierarchies. But Armstrong draws attention to the carpets' original weavers, often female and illiterate, whose artistry remains a source of awe.

God and Sex, by Jon Raymond (Simon & Schuster). In this lush novel, which reconsiders the meaning of an "act of God," a moderately successful writer of New Age nonfiction decides to focus his next treatise on trees. As he conducts research, he insinuates himself into the lives of an ecology professor and his wife, soon beginning an affair with the latter. The writer and the professor's wife (whose dalliances Raymond renders through a series of rather explicit coital vignettes) discover that they may have a transcendent connection, but then a forest fire seems to take the wife's life. In the wake of catastrophe, the writer's ambiguous relationship to God begins to reveal itself.

Dominion, by Addie E. Citchens (Farrar, Straus & Giroux). This début novel of Southern small-town life considers the hypocrisies forged in patriarchy's crucible and the difficulty of reckoning with a father's sins. Priscilla, the proud yet put-upon matriarch of the most powerful family in Dominion, Mississippi, and a quiet teen-ager named Diamond, whose future is as uncertain as her childhood has been tumultuous, share a love for the town's golden boy, who is Priscilla's son. The young man's beauty, musical talents, and athletic prowess, however, belie volatile currents of desire and rage, which will eventually scandalize the community and unsettle Priscilla and Diamond's faiths.

urn:contentItem:6GKN-T7K3-RSYT-V1J4-00000-00Tenbury fire crews called to large fire and fire in the open2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisTenbury fire crews called to large fire and fire in the openJulia Baker

TENBURY WELLS fire crews were in for a busy Bank Holiday shift, as they tackled a fire in the open, a fire alarm, and a large fire.

The fire station's Bank Holiday Monday shift saw the crew first mobilised at around midday to a fire in the open in the Stoke Bliss area, with crew from Leominster Fire Station also in attendance.

After returning to the station at 3pm, just an hour and a half later, they were called to provide standby cover to Wyre Forest Fire Station.

However, the crews were quickly sent on to an automatic fire alarm in the Wyre Forest area.

From there, they were sent back to standby duties at Wyre Forest.

Just after 6pm, the firefighters were sent on to reinspect the earlier incident in Stoke Bliss, but before arriving, they were redirected to a large fire in the open with crews from Wyre Forest, Bromsgrove Fire Station and Leominster's water carrier at around 7pm.

The crew left at around 9.30pm and went to reinspect the earlier fire at Stoke Bliss, where the incident was closed and then finally returned to the home station at 11pm.

Tenbury Fire Station is based on Worcester Road in Burford, and is overseen by station commander Richard Young.

The station is staffed by on-call firefighters, who are also water-first responders, allowing them to attend water-related incidents which other fire crews are not normally trained to do.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-T0P3-RRT8-C2N4-00000-00Activists throw paint on Barcelona's Sagrada Familia over Spain fires2025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisActivists throw paint on Barcelona's Sagrada Familia over Spain firesThe Peninsula Newspaper

Madrid: Climate activists daubed Barcelona's Sagrada Familia basilica with red and black paint on Sunday to express outrage at summer forest fires that have ravaged swaths of Spain, the Futuro Vegetal activist group said.

In a video the group posted to social media, police officers are seen arresting two protesters as they shouted for "climate justice".

The Sagrada Familia, designed by Catalan architect Antoni Gaudi, is one of Barcelona's main tourist attractions.

Futuro Vegetal slammed what it alleged is insufficient government action on climate change, notably to quell the recent clutch of fires that have caused extensive damage.

The fires have left four people dead and ravaged some 350,000 hectares of land (870,00 acres) in the past fortnight alone, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

Spain's government called the fires "one of the biggest environmental catastrophes" the country has witnessed in recent memory, and acknowledged a link with climate change.

This weekend saw the scope of the problem recede, with civil protection services director Virginia Barcones saying Saturday that the emergency was "coming to an end".

Futuro Vegetal, which has links to similar groups abroad, has staged dozens of similar protests, including one in 2022 when they glued their hands to the frames of paintings by Spanish master Francisco de Goya at Madrid's Prado Museum.

Paint was also thrown at a super yacht in Ibiza reportedly belonging to Nancy Walton Laurie, the billionaire heiress of US retail giant Walmart, and a mansion of former FC Barcelona star Lionel Messi in Ibiza.

Spanish police said last year they had arrested 22 members of Futuro Vegetal, including the two who took part in the Prado protest and the group's three main leaders.

urn:contentItem:6GMP-6DR3-S15R-80HP-00000-00Senamhi warns of temperatures dropping to -20 °C in the southern highlands this September 1st.2025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSenamhi warns of temperatures dropping to -20 °C in the southern highlands this September 1st.


The National Meteorological and Hydrological Service (Senamhi) reported that this Monday, September 1, the high Andean areas of six departments of the southern highlands will experience a marked drop in nighttime temperatures, which will reach values close to -20 °C in localities located above 4,000 meters above sea level.


According to weather warning No. 307, with an orange alert level, moderate to strong cold is expected, accompanied by wind gusts that could reach up to 50 km/h. In addition, scarce cloudiness and temperature increase during the day are expected.
The departments included in this forecast are Apurímac, Arequipa, Cusco, Moquegua, Puno and Tacna.
The National Civil Defense Institute (Indeci) urged the population to take preventive measures to reduce health risks. Among the main recommendations are:

Avoid exposure to sudden temperature changes.

Cover head, face and mouth to protect lungs from cold air.

Use appropriate warm clothing (sweaters, gloves, hats).

Protect especially children and older adults.

In case of symptoms of respiratory infections, go immediately to the nearest health center.


It is also suggested to consume warm drinks, fruits, fresh vegetables, sweets and fats that help increase resistance to cold, in addition to storing food and drinking water in safe places.
Indeci, through the National Emergency Operations Center (COEN), informed that it is monitoring the alerted departments and coordinating actions with regional and local authorities to mitigate the effects of this meteorological phenomenon.

urn:contentItem:6GTN-BVB3-RRXY-N27K-00000-00Reports Outline Science Findings from Togliatti State University (The impact of fires on mosquito populations in Eastern Siberian forests)2025-09-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSCIENCEReports Outline Science Findings from Togliatti State University (The impact of fires on mosquito populations in Eastern Siberian forests)


2025 SEP 24 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Zika & Mosquito Daily -- A new study on Science is now available. According to news reporting originating in Togliatti, Russia, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Forest fires have a significant impact on forest fauna, killing not only mammals and birds, but also less noticeable representatives of forest fauna - insects. Existing research have mainly studied the effects on vertebrate taxa, but the data on the effects of fires on the number of insects living in forests is currently insufficient to cover all the groups."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Togliatti State University, "The research presented in this paper examines the immediate impact of forest fires on the number of adults in mosquito populations (Culicidae) in burned areas of the boreal forest. The data were collected in the boreal forests of Eastern Siberia, in the Republic of Sakha (Yakutia). Field survey was conducted in ten forest areas, including five recently burned and five unburned areas. Mosquitoes were caught in flight and counted during daylight hours within the time span of 7 days after the fire. We compared the data obtained from burned and unburned adjacent forest plots, which allowed us to establish the level of immediate impact of forest fires on the abundance of adult mosquito populations in the burned plots of the boreal forest. In all five pairs of forest plots, a decrease in the abundance of adult mosquitoes was noted, within the range of 86.6-93.9%. The data clearly show a lower number of adult mosquitoes for several days after the forest fire. The results obtained are of interest for further studying, regardless of the medical significance of mosquitoes, with consideration of their role in boreal ecosystems."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study is planned to be continued over the next few years in order to obtain new data on the impact of forest fires on mosquito populations in a medium and long term, which will allow us to form a broader vision of this problem."
For more information on this research see: The impact of fires on mosquito populations in Eastern Siberian forests. PLOS One, 2025;20(9). PLOS One can be contacted at: Public Library Science, 1160 Battery Street, Ste 100, San Francisco, CA 94111, USA. (Public Library of Science - www.plos.org; PLOS One - www.plosone.org)
Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Alexey V. Shvetsov, Togliatti State University, Togliatti, Russia.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0326366. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
The publisher of the journal PLOS One can be contacted at: Public Library Science, 1160 Battery Street, Ste 100, San Francisco, CA 94111, USA.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4FX3-RT5B-B29S-00000-00Charagua Iyambae declares disaster due to fires in Ñembi Guasu2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisCharagua Iyambae declares disaster due to fires in Ñembi Guasu


The Legislative Body of the Indigenous Autonomous Government of Charagua Iyambae (GAIOC) declared a disaster due to the forest fires affecting the Ñembi Guasu protected area.
According to a report from the Sumando Voces portal, on Tuesday Autonomy Law 07/2025 was approved and enacted, declaring a disaster due to the forest fires in the area.


"The purpose of the autonomous law is to declare a disaster situation due to forest fires in the area of conservation and ecological importance Ñembi Guasu in the Autonomous Indigenous Indigenous Original Peasant Government of Charagua Iyambae," the regulation states.
The report indicates that the regulation responds to technical, legal and financial reports that demonstrate the magnitude of the damages caused by the fire in the reserve and exceed the economic and technical capacity of the autonomous government to respond on its own.
Article 1 of the law establishes the declaration of disaster within the framework of Law 602, on Risk Management, and Law 031, on Autonomies; while Article 3 stipulates that GAIOC's Executive Body coordinates humanitarian assistance, rehabilitation of flora and fauna, and recovery of the natural landscape with departmental and national authorities.
Ñembi Guasu
The regulation also orders the immediate activation of the Emergency Operations Center (COE) to coordinate risk management and articulate the response to the emergency. The declaration will remain in effect until a technical evaluation determines the reduction of the fires according to the contingency plan.
Charagua Iyambae immediately activated legal and administrative mechanisms that will allow access to resources and external assistance to face one of the most serious disasters in recent years in its autonomous territory.
The Vice Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes, informed that on Monday Bolivia closed with 1,462 hot spots, distributed mainly in Santa Cruz (684), Beni (584), Pando (93), Chuquisaca (12), Potosí (15), Cochabamba (19) and Oruro (7).
He said that firefighters are working to extinguish the only active forest fire in the Ñembi Guasu reserve.

urn:contentItem:6GPT-XJ63-SH9C-52DP-00000-00Red alert in 24 municipalities due to forest fires2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisRed alert in 24 municipalities due to forest fires


p>The Vice-Ministry of Civil Defense has reported that 24 municipalities in Bolivia are under red alert and 62 under orange alert due to the increase of forest fires. Santa Cruz is the most affected department in this situation. Currently, there are seven active fires in the country, highlighting one that persists in the Noel Kempff Mercado National Park.


Details of the alert in municipalities
The Vice-Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes, has indicated that Santa Cruz has 18 municipalities in red alert and 20 in orange alert. Other departments that also have municipalities in red alert are Tarija with three, Beni with two and La Paz with one. As for orange alert, Beni has 17, Pando registers 15, and Chuquisaca and Cochabamba have five each.
"With this we demonstrate that we are starting a very complicated period in the country, taking into account that last year forest fires in September had their highest peak," said Calvimontes.
Active fires in the country
Regarding forest fires, Santa Cruz has four active fires in the municipalities of Concepción, El Carmen Rivero Tórrez, San Ignacio de Velasco and San Matías. Beni has two fires: one in San Ramón and another in San Andrés. La Paz has one active fire in Ixiamas.
Hot spots and their distribution
The latest data from the Vice-Ministry of Defense indicate that Santa Cruz has 502 hot spots, Beni 263, La Paz 23 and Cochabamba 22.
Actions in the National Park
Calvimontes also analyzed the situation of forest fires in the department of Santa Cruz, especially the one that persists in the Noel Kempff Mercado National Park. From a coordination meeting, immediate actions were defined to strengthen the operational capacity to fight the fire in this protected area.
"By Friday, the Vice Ministry of Civil Defense is assigning a helicopter to operate specifically in Noel Kempff Mercado Park. All the paperwork is being done for the mobilization of aerial fuel to reach Florida," Calvimontes added.
Intervention in Concepción
Finally, it has been determined to intervene immediately in the municipality of Concepción, where a forest fire has persisted for four days and "unfortunately" the Municipal Mayor's Office is not reacting according to Law 602.
/KMMN
The post Red alert in 24 municipalities due to forest fires first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

urn:contentItem:6GR9-DY63-RRJ2-V1TD-00000-00Fire2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisFireSrinagar

Srinagar, Sept. 13 -- The most tangible, of all the mysteries, that this universe has to offer, is 'fire', aag, agni, the flamboyant, blazing, orange tongues of leaping fire, are actually celestial sparks, that you can peer into for hours, without being able to unravel their seething heart. The dynamism and zest in human hearts, has the capacity to be a conflagration.

On the other hand, a holocaust of fervent fanatics, can paint a perfectly beautiful heaven into hell ! - a raging forest fire is a powerful force. It can be seen for miles, fuming and scalding whatever comes in its way, while looking like a million bucks ! kindling even a small campfire, can be tough, if you lack the technique. The fire in our hearts, though has to be like molten lava, oozing out in a passionate arousal, of rainbow dreams. "chullhe agg na ghadde de vich paani, chhaddeyaan di joon buri."

Man has, always had the knack, of playing with fire, whether it is hearts or bullets. The thrill of looking up at the night sky, to see the fireworks, lighting up the firmament, with the "aatish baazi", must have started with the mughal emperor, Babar's first artillery fire in India. "Ek aag ka dariya hai, aur doob ke jaana hai" was perhaps the most apt summing up of "ishq." Fire mesmerizes and hypnotizes, fire thrills and intrigues, making one forget that it has a burning and raging heart. The irony is that, though a tiny spark can become a smoking and throbbing fire, yet all fires go out eventually !.

Who can explain to a heart on fire to wear protective gear.? Gold has to prove its purity by the test of fire. Fire in the heart, often befuddles and bemuses the head with smoke, the same fire, both enlightens and consumes. The moth and the candle are ample testimony to this saga 'shama jis aag mein jalti hai numaaish ke liye, hum ussi aag mein gumnaam se jal jaate hain aur." 'bujh gayee ek aah mein sham me hayaat, mujh ko ek aah sard ne thhanda kiya - zulmat kade mein mere shab e gham ka josh hai, ikk shamma hai daleel e sahar, so khaamosh hai

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RH73-S7KW-C2PK-00000-00Fires in "Complejo San Pedro Mártir" and "Rosa De Castilla" in Sierra de Juárez declared extinguished2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisFires in "Complejo San Pedro Mártir" and "Rosa De Castilla" in Sierra de Juárez declared extinguished


Ensenada, Baja California - The State Coordination of Civil Protection reports that, based on information from the National Forestry Commission (CONAFOR), after 19 uninterrupted days of combat, control and liquidation operations, the fires that made up the San Pedro Mártir Complex have been declared liquidated. The total preliminary affected area amounts to 2,383 hectares, the sum of the fires Tasajera 1, Tasajera 2, La Encantada and Santa Rosa, with 100% control and 100% liquidation in the four branches.


In the Sierra de Juárez, the "Rosa de Castilla" forest fire was liquidated, with a preliminary affected area of 929 hectares, and 100 % control and 100 % liquidation.
During the day today, and after the morning rain in the area, vigilance was maintained in the last two active perimeters and a monitoring flight was conducted over the four affected areas of the complex, with no new developments detected.
Fighters and technical personnel from CONAFOR, Comisión Nacional de Áreas Naturales Protegidas (CONANP), Secretaría de Medio Ambiente y Desarrollo Sustentable de Baja California (SMADS), Protección Civil Estatal, Observatorio de San Pedro Mártir, Terra Peninsular, Universidad Autónoma de Baja California (UABC) and Rancho La Concepción participated in the actions.
Photo: Courtesy.
As a preventive measure, continuous surveillance will be maintained in the area to monitor possible reactivations and ensure the stability of the perimeters, by means of periodic ground patrols and reconnaissance overflights, in coordination with the participating agencies.
The population is invited to prevent forest fires by not lighting campfires or barbecues in natural areas, not throwing cigarette butts, matches, bottles or garbage, and suspending cleaning or agricultural burns. In case of identifying smoke or fire, report it immediately to 9-1-1.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y603-RS3T-S0VW-00000-00Fire in Tolata remains active and forces brigades to retreat due to strong winds2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisFire in Tolata remains active and forces brigades to retreat due to strong winds


A forest fire started on the afternoon of September 8 in the Tolata mountain range, located in the high valley of Cochabamba. This fire is still active this Tuesday due to strong winds that complicate its control. The Risk Management Unit (UGR) of the Governor's Office has indicated that this situation has led to the withdrawal of personnel for safety reasons, while the brigades are reorganized to continue fighting the fire.


Ramiro López, head of the UGR, commented to Unitel that the decision to withdraw the teams was taken for safety reasons, since wind gusts were preventing them from operating normally. He also pointed out that on Monday work was carried out until late at night, which shows the complexity of the situation.
Support from brigades and volunteers
During the morning, brigades from the Bolivian Air Force Search and Rescue Service (SAR-FAB) and volunteer groups joined the operation. These units worked in coordination with the municipality and other institutions in order to control the flames in Tolata and prevent them from spreading to other areas.
Origin and spread of the fire
The fire originated in Sacaba and, due to the force of the winds, moved to Tolata, affecting large wooded areas. While in Sacaba the fire has been contained, in Tolata the flames are still active and the brigades are focusing their efforts on protecting nearby communities.
"It has been growing, yesterday it was quite windy and these are favorable conditions for the development of the fire. Now it is being fought from this municipality (Tolata)," said López, highlighting the difficulties generated by geography and wind.
Impact and damage assessment
There is still no official estimate of the number of hectares affected, but the authorities assure that the figure will be revealed when the fire is completely under control. This is another fire affecting Cochabamba in a few weeks, after more than 350 hectares of Tunari Park were consumed by flames at the end of August.
Causes of the fire
At the moment the causes of the fire in Tolata are unknown, although it is not ruled out that it was intentional, as has happened in other recent cases in the department.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y5M3-RRRC-62KY-00000-00Agro-environmental Court grants 48 hours to authorities to mitigate fires2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisAgro-environmental Court grants 48 hours to authorities to mitigate fires


The Agro-environmental Court has issued a resolution that establishes a 48-hour term for national and sub-national authorities to implement precautionary measures aimed at mitigating forest fires in the country.


This announcement is made in the context of the red alert declared by the Governor's Office of Santa Cruz, due to the presence of seven active fires and 165 hot spots in the region, on September 8, 2025.
Consequences of non-compliance
The resolution warns that, in case of non-compliance, the background information will be sent to the Public Prosecutor's Office to initiate criminal proceedings. "A non-extendable term of 48 hours from the date of notification of this resolution is granted to comply with the precautionary measures set forth above, with the prevention that in case of non-compliance, the records will be sent to the Public Prosecutor's Office in order to initiate criminal proceedings for non-compliance with judicial resolutions", states point 1 of the resolution of the Agro-environmental Tribunal.
Instructions to agro-environmental judges
The decision was taken in full court and instructs the agro-environmental judges, especially those operating in the Amazon and the Chaco, to activate their environmental jurisdiction ex officio. This includes the inspection, control and supervision of mitigation and emergency response actions.
The judges should prepare detailed and documented reports on the emergency response and forest fire mitigation plans, as well as supervise their compliance.
Scheduling Inspections
In addition, they are instructed to schedule inspections in the areas of greatest risk, with the specialized technical support of the Agro-environmental Court. This measure was announced by the director of Natural Resources, Paulo Viruez. "With this, the activation of the Municipal Emergency Operations Committees (COEM) proceeds in order to have the necessary resources and personnel to attend to these forest fires in their respective municipalities," Viruez emphasized.
Municipalities at risk
Currently, there are 26 municipalities with high, very high and extreme risk levels for the occurrence of forest fires. Likewise, the approval of contingency and emergency plans is requested, as established by Law 300 on risk management and emergency response.
/KMMN

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y623-RS92-21SN-00000-00Rimac: Man shot after resisting assault in front of his home2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisRimac: Man shot after resisting assault in front of his home


A 57-year-old man was the victim of a violent assault and ended up seriously wounded after resisting the attack in Rimac.
The victim was identified as Alex Carranza Ventosilla, who was shot in the abdomen in front of his home located in jirón 29 de marzo, reported América Noticias.


According to the account of a friend who was with him that night, both had attended a meeting and, upon returning, decided to sit down on a staircase to eat. At that moment, a minivan stopped in front of them and immediately criminals got out with the intention of robbing them. Carranza resisted the robbery and one of the assailants shot him.
The impact left him lying on the ground with a serious wound. Neighbors and family members immediately came to his aid while a patrol car from the Piedra Liza police station arrived.
With the support of the officers, the wounded man was rushed to the Hipólito Unanue hospital, where he remains hospitalized under medical observation. Doctors were evaluating the complexity of the injury to determine if surgery would be necessary.
One of his sisters explained that Alex works in private security and was scheduled to travel to the interior of the country this Wednesday. She also regretted that crime is hitting citizens who are engaged in honest activities.
The relative asked for guarantees so that Carranza can recover and urged the authorities to reinforce vigilance in the district, where, she said, robberies occur at any time of the day.
Meanwhile, neighbors of jirón 29 de marzo denounced that in the last few weeks robberies have increased and that the criminals move around in vehicles to surprise their victims.
In view of this situation, they demanded the National Police and the Serenazgo del Rímac to intensify patrols, mainly in areas where the presence of armed criminals has become constant.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-M0M3-RRY6-500M-00000-00Arrested a woman from Carballo (A Coruña) accused of starting 11 forest fires2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisArrested a woman from Carballo (A Coruña) accused of starting 11 forest fires


The Nature Protection Service (SEPRONA) of the Command of the Civil Guard of A Coruña, in collaboration with other units of the Command, has arrested a resident of Carballo as the alleged perpetrator of 11 crimes of forest fire.


The Armed Institute reports that the arrest has occurred in the framework of the exploitation phase of the Monte Fumeiro operation, which began as a result of the fire occurred on July 10 in the parish of Entrecruces. In the course of this operation, 10 other forest fires occurred on July 31 and on August 5, 7, 8, 9, 11, 16, 17, 18 and 19 in the same area.
The fires were of little importance due to the rapid intervention of the fire-fighting services, which required a permanent surveillance of the area and the withdrawal of personnel from other areas. This, as indicated by the Guardia Civil, has a "consequent repercussion" in the current context of large fires, where numerous troops are mobilized.
Following the investigation work carried out, the Civil Guards were able to identify the alleged perpetrator of the offenses. Once the identity was known, the Civil Guard proceeded to arrest her for allegedly causing a total of 11 forest fires. The detainee, along with the actions carried out, was placed at the disposal of the Court of Instruction number 3 of Carballo.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y603-RS3T-S301-00000-00Santiváñez defends amnesty law at UN and announces evaluation of inter-American system2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSantiváñez defends amnesty law at UN and announces evaluation of inter-American system


The Minister of Justice and Human Rights, Juan José Santiváñez, spoke before the United Nations Human Rights Council to support the amnesty law recently approved in Peru.
During his presentation, he emphasized that the measure is framed within the principle of separation of powers and the sovereignty of the Peruvian State.


According to him, the law was conceived as a response to the actions of terrorism, which in past decades tried to undermine democratic institutions and caused serious damage to the population.
In this line, he specified that the approval of the law corresponds to a decision of the Congress that is part of its constitutional attributions and reflects the autonomy of the powers of the State.
Santiváñez affirmed that the Government maintains its commitment with the strengthening of the rule of law, the defense of democracy and the promotion of human rights. In addition, he recalled that the country is moving forward in the preparation of elections which, under the administration of President Dina Boluarte, must be guaranteed with transparency and legality.
The Minister also addressed the recent resolution issued by the Inter-American Court of Human Rights regarding the amnesty law.
In this context, he warned that the Peruvian State is evaluating the possibility of reviewing its permanence within the Inter-American human rights system, as well as the substantive and procedural frameworks that regulate it.
However, he indicated that this review does not mean a distancing from international cooperation. On the contrary, he stated that Peru will continue to coordinate efforts with the Office of the High Commissioner of the United Nations to advance in the protection of fundamental rights.
In another moment, the Minister of Justice emphasized that freedom, independence and self-determination are principles that must be respected without external interference. He considered that this approach is essential to ensure the stability of States and the solidity of their democratic institutions.

urn:contentItem:6GPG-BVP3-RSM9-X07R-00000-00Ladies' Tournament Golfers Endure Scorching Heat in Hope2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisLadies' Tournament Golfers Endure Scorching Heat in Hope

In spite of intense heat and smoke from Yale forest fire, 38 players from Hope, the Lower Mainland and the Okanagan enjoyed two days of golf and social activities sponsored by the Ladies' Club of the the Hope Golf Course.

Golf partners played a Scramble on Saturday, Aug. 23 and a Scotch Ball on Sunday, Aug. 24. In order to encourage new players, a new division requiring no handicap was added this year for the first day of play. Players with a handicap played on both days.

Practice rounds on Friday and appetizers in the evening were followed by a putting contest won by Tracy Macfarlane sinking a long putt. Second place went to Sharyn Harvey.

Minjeong Kim and Jennifer Eum, both of Langley, captured Overall Low Gross for the second year in a row with a score of 144.

Overall Low Net , with a score of 125, was won by Hope locals Diane Field and Shelley Simpson.

Other Hope winners included Tracy Macfarlane, 2nd Low Gross; Pam Testawich and Virginia White,1st Low Net; Tammy Shields and June Lowe, 2nd Low Net; Anna Johnstad-Moeller and Pam Smith, 1st Low Gross; Inge Wilson and Deb Dixon, 1st Low Net; and Jessica McWilliams, 2nd Low Net.

Back by popular demand, the duo "Room to Dance" from West Kelowna provided toe-tapping music that got everyone up and dancing after a full course buffet on Saturday evening.

Tournament Coordinator Macfarlane made a point of honouring several people in her address to the players, including past coordinator Keren Hasell who spearheaded the event for several very successful years. She also recalled two very active and dearly missed members of the Hope Ladies' Club, Alice Woods and Tama Kawase, both of whom passed away this year.

Fay Stewart continued the tradition of providing several amusing floral touches around the course.

The tournament would not have been possible without the help of over 30 sponsors as well as the many volunteers who made sure the tournament ran smoothly.

Largely due to unflagging work and support from multiple volunteers, the course has come a long way in recovering from a devastating flood in 2021. Great work from greenskeeper Mike Carrier and his crew continue to bring the course up to its full potential.

The Hope Ladies Golf Club always welcomes new players to join.
