urn:contentItem:6GK5-N6Y3-RYJY-61BX-00000-00Spain's recent heatwave most intense on record: agency2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSSpain's recent heatwave most intense on record: agencyPaul Giblin,Huang Yan

MADRID, Aug. 24 (Xinhua) -- Spain's State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) said Sunday that the heatwave striking the country this August was the most intense on record, both in terms of temperatures and impacts.

According to provisional data, average temperatures during the Aug. 3-18 period were 4.6 degrees Celsius above the seasonal norm, surpassing the previous record of 4.5 degrees Celsius set in July 2022. AEMET noted that Aug. 8-17 marked the hottest 10 consecutive days since at least 1950, while the first 20 days of August were the hottest for that period since at least 1961. The days of Aug. 11, 16, and 17 rank among the 10 hottest days registered in Spain since 1941. Since records began in 1975, Spain has experienced 77 heatwaves. Six of these saw temperatures exceed the average by 4 degrees Celsius, with five occurring since 2019, indicating a trend toward longer and more intense heatwaves. According to the government's Daily Mortality Monitoring System, this year's heatwaves have caused 1,149 deaths. In addition, the extreme heat coincided with Spain's worst month of wildfires on record. Data from the European Forest Fire Information System show that 406,100 hectares of land, roughly 5.5 times the size of Singapore, have been burned. The fires have claimed four lives and forced over 30,000 people to evacuate. Most evacuees have since returned, but many wildfires remained active as of Sunday. Enditem

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DGK3-RS8V-R03X-00000-00Warning from the Guardia Civil to all of Spain: from now on, be careful if your neighbors do this for cooking2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisWarning from the Guardia Civil to all of Spain: from now on, be careful if your neighbors do this for cooking


The Nature Protection Service (Seprona) of the Command of the Civil Guard of Leon, in collaboration with Environmental agents of the Board, has arrested a 75 year old man, as the alleged perpetrator of the forest fire declared on Sunday, August 24, in the municipality of Molinaseca (Leon).


In depth
Once the investigators moved to the place of the beginning of the fire, they verified, after the corresponding technical ocular inspection, that the origin of the fire could have its origin in a bonfire made for cooking by the person now arrested, details the Armed Institute through a statement.
On the part of the Seprona of the Civil Guard, once fully identified the alleged perpetrator and collected incriminating evidence of its origin, has instructed the corresponding criminal proceedings for referral to the Court of Instruction of Guardia de Ponferrada (León), as well as the Prosecutor's Office of Environment and Urban Planning Area of Ponferrada.
More details
"In this fire, as in all those originated in the province of León, the Civil Guard is deployed at all points of interest where its presence is required to provide the necessary assistance, evacuating the towns that are determined, regulating traffic on the affected roads, and, in short, complying with the instructions dictated by the CECOPI on the progress of the outbreaks, having constantly in the same a liaison person," the statement ends.

urn:contentItem:6GMY-PXH3-RS1X-24K6-00000-00WILDFIRE NEARS FORT PROVIDENCE AS CREWS RACE TO PROTECT COMMUNITY2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexis8:00 AM ESTCBC Radio OneMARCIA YOUNGDANNY BEAULIEUJUANITA TAYLORRUBY MINOZARJ SIMPSONWR2509024WILDFIRE NEARS FORT PROVIDENCE AS CREWS RACE TO PROTECT COMMUNITY

MARCIA YOUNG (CBC-RADIO):
Structural firefighters are standing by in case of an out-of-control wildfire reaching Fort Providence. Northwest Territories Fire says the flames came within 900 metres of the community yesterday, but fuel breaks have been built and crews are trying to keep the area damp. Juanita Taylor has more on the work being done to try to protect homes.



DANNY BEAULIEU (MAYOR OF FORT PROVIDENCE):
These cats are working here. They're tightlining the, the fire.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
Danny Beaulieu is working to strengthen the fire break on the outskirts of Fort Providence. He is also the mayor protecting his community from the raging wildfire.

DANNY BEAULIEU (MAYOR OF FORT PROVIDENCE):
They have hoses laid all over the town, sprinklers up on the houses, especially the houses what we call the back street along the tree line.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
The wildfire is pushing towards town. Some essential workers were ordered out Monday, a day after residents began to flee to Hay River, 180 kilometres away. Evacuee Ruby Minoza is worried.

RUBY MINOZA (EVACUEE):
Am I going to go home? Is my house still going to be standing up when I get home or are my grandkids going to have a house to go home to.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
The wildfire is one of dozens burning in the Northwest Territories. Premier RJ Simpson wants more federal support.

RJ SIMPSON (PREMIER OF THE NORTHWEST TERRITORIES):
We're a small jurisdiction, and we can only handle so much. We only have so much capacity, but with the world the way it is, with climate change and the frequency and severity of these disasters, it's tough. It's, we're stretched.

JUANITA TAYLOR (REPORTER):
Simpson says the territory has reached out to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre for more crews and aircraft to fight this fire. Come midweek, winds are expected to pick up again towards Fort Providence. Juanita Taylor, CBC News, Hay River, Northwest Territories.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DGK3-RS8V-R08M-00000-00Spain suffered this month the most intense heat wave in its history2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisSpain suffered this month the most intense heat wave in its history


Madrid (Xinhua) - Spain's State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) reported that the heat wave that hit the country this August was the most intense on record, both in terms of temperatures and impacts.


According to provisional data, average temperatures from August 3 to 18 exceeded the seasonal average by 4.6 degrees Celsius, thus surpassing the previous record of 4.5 degrees Celsius set in July 2022.
The AEMET noted that August 8-17 saw the 10 warmest consecutive days since at least 1950, while the first 20 days of August were the warmest for that period since at least 1961.
August 11, 16 and 17 were among the 10 hottest days recorded in Spain since 1941 and, since records began in 1975, Spain experienced 77 heat waves.
According to the government's Daily Mortality Monitoring System, this year's heat waves caused 1,149 deaths. In addition, the extreme heat coincided with the worst month of forest fires on record in Spain.
Data from the European Forest Fire Information System show that 406,100 hectares of land burned, about 5.5 times the size of Singapore.
The fires caused four deaths and forced the evacuation of more than 30,000 people, most of whom returned to their homes, although many wildfires were still active as of Sunday.
The post Spain suffered this month the most intense heat wave in its history appeared first on Diario San Rafael.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-WHG3-RRN0-Y2G9-00000-00First Nation residents prepare to evacuate2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A13First Nation residents prepare to evacuateThe Canadian Press

Evacuation preparations are underway in a First Nation community in Northwest Territories as a wildfire burns nearby.

The territory's No. 1 priority fire grew four kilometres overnight and now burns about 8.5 kilometres southwest of Whatì. Strong overnight winds are lighter on Thursday, but continue to push the blaze toward the community, officials say.

"I think we are ready for a possible evacuation, and it looks like it's going to happen," said Sherbaz Muhammad, the community government's senior administrative officer, in an interview Thursday morning. "We've been hoping, wishing that we'll stay, but I think it's not just the smoke. It looks like the fire is so close."

Wildfire smoke has choked the skies and made it difficult for airtankers to help fight the flames.

The air quality in the region was considered a very high health risk as of Thursday morning, prompting widespread warnings from Environment Canada.

In Whatì, officials say sprinklers are being set up around the community and the fire department is creating a water barrier along the lone road out of the community, which runs south, back toward fire danger.

Winds are expected to shift on Friday and come from the north, which could turn the fire burning near Whati back on itself, officials say.

Muhammad says if they have to evacuate, the community will be hosted in Behchoko, the nearest community by road located about 160 kilometres away.

A stretch of that drive is along Highway 3, where territorial officials are warning drivers of "extreme conditions," with flames visible in some areas and heavy smoke.

Fire crews were battling 10 out-of-control wildfires in the territory as of Wednesday, according to the latest update posted by the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9VM3-RXXX-81F8-00000-00Fires have burned more than 362,000 hectares across Spain between August 1 and 21, according to Copernicus2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisFires have burned more than 362,000 hectares across Spain between August 1 and 21, according to Copernicus


Forest fires have burned a total of 362,473 hectares throughout Spain between August 1 and 21, according to data from the European Commission's Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus.


This has advanced this Wednesday the third vice president of the Government and Minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, Sara Agesen Muñoz, during his appearance in the Senate to report on the measures taken by his Ministry to the serious situation of forest fires affecting different territories with a severe impact on the environment, biodiversity and ecosystem.
In the case of Galicia, the estimate would be 158,000 hectares burned in that period; in Castilla y León, 150,000 hectares; in Extremadura, 45,000 hectares; in Asturias, 2,405 hectares; and in Madrid, 2,338 hectares. Smaller areas were also affected in Andalusia, Navarre and Castile-La Mancha.
Large forest fires affected 97% of the area affected. The wooded area affected is estimated at 140,000 hectares and the area of Protected Natural Spaces and the Natura 2000 Network affected by the fires is estimated at approximately 160,000 hectares.
Also affected have been critical areas for the survival of 395 vulnerable endangered species or under special protection regime of the LESPRE list, such as the capercaillie, in 2,400 hectares, or the black stork, in 773 hectares, or the brown bear, in 1,751 hectares.
"It is an analysis that we will have to go into in greater depth and that we will work on, of course," said the Minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88P3-RXCR-B0HX-00000-00The King and Queen of Spain begin their visit to the areas affected by the Jarilla fire (Cáceres)2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisThe King and Queen of Spain begin their visit to the areas affected by the Jarilla fire (Cáceres)


Felipe VI and Doña Letizia have begun this Friday their tour of some of the places most affected by the forest fire in Jarilla (Cáceres), considered the most virulent in the recent history of Extremadura and that devastated 17,350 hectares.


They have landed in Rebollar, where they have been received by the President of Extremadura, María Guardiola the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Grande-Marlaska, and the mayoress of this town in Cáceres, Petra Díaz.
The objectives of these visits, which began on Wednesday in Castilla y León, is to know first hand the damages suffered and the needs of the affected neighbors, as well as to show their gratitude to all the teams that have contributed to fight the fire and protect the population.
In Rebollar, the only evacuated village in the Jerte valley, they will hold a meeting with those affected both in this town and in other municipalities of Cáceres, as well as with representatives of the beekeeping, livestock, agricultural, tourism and agrotourism sectors.
After the meeting, they will travel to Cabezabellosa, the first municipality evacuated together with Jarilla and Villar de Plasencia on August 12. There, they will meet with representatives of the troops who took part in the fire extinction and help to those affected.
The King and Queen will end their visit in Hervás, where they will meet with the mayors of the municipalities affected by the fire and will be able to know the situation of these towns and their plans for recovery and future, according to sources from the Royal Household.

urn:contentItem:6GXN-3CB3-RYS9-H1FK-00000-00Could LAFD have done more to prevent rekindling of Palisades fire?2025-10-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisCould LAFD have done more to prevent rekindling of Palisades fire?Alene Tchekmedyian, Richard Winton

Federal investigators have determined that the wildfire that leveled much of Pacific Palisades on Jan. 7 was a so-called "holdover" from a smaller fire that was set intentionally on New Year's Day, about a week earlier.

After Los Angeles firefighters suppressed the Jan. 1 fire known as the Lachman fire, it continued to smolder and burn underground, "unbeknownst to anyone," according to federal officials. They said heavy winds six days later caused the underground fire to surface and spread above ground in what became one of the costliest and most destructive disasters in city history.

The revelations - unveiled in a criminal complaint and attached affidavit Wednesday charging the alleged arsonist, Jonathan Rinderknecht - raise questions about what the Los Angeles Fire Department could have done to prevent the conflagration in the days leading up to the expected windstorm on Jan. 7 and the extraordinary fire risk that would come with it.

"This affidavit puts the responsibility on the fire department," said Ed Nordskog, former head of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department's arson unit. "There needs to be a commission examining why this rekindled fire was allowed to reignite."

He added: "The arsonist set the first fire, but the Fire Department proactively has a duty to do certain things."

A Times investigation found that LAFD officials did not pre-deploy any engines to the Palisades ahead of the Jan. 7 fire, despite warnings about extreme weather. In preparing for the winds, the department staffed up only five of more than 40 engines available to supplement the regular firefighting force.

Those engines could have been pre-positioned in the Palisades and elsewhere, as had been done in the past during similar weather.

Kenny Cooper, special agent in charge of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives who was involved in the investigation into the Palisades fire's origin, said the blame for the fire's re-ignition lies solely with the person who started it.

"That fire burned deep within the ground, in roots and in structure, and remained active for several days," Cooper said. "No matter how good they are, they can't see that, right?"

But, he said, wildland firefighters commonly patrol for days or weeks to prevent re-ignitions.

When he worked at a state forestry agency, he said, "we would have a lightning strike, and it would hit a tree, and it would burn for days, sometimes weeks, and then ignite into a forest fire. We would go suppress that, and then every day, for weeks on end, we would patrol those areas to make sure they didn't reignite," he said. "If we saw evidence of smoke or heat, then we would provide resources to that. So that, I know that's a common practice, and it's just, it's a very difficult fire burning underground."

The affidavit provides a window into the firefighting timeline on Jan. 1, when just after midnight, the Lachman fire was ignited near a small clearing near the Temescal Ridge Trail.

12:13 a.m.: An image taken from a UCSD camera, approximately two-tenths of a mile away, shows a bright spot in the upper left - the Lachman fire.

12:20 a.m.: Rinderknecht drives down Palisades Drive, passing fire engines heading up Palisades Drive, responding to the fire.

That night, the LAFD, with help from the Los Angeles County Fire Department, used water drops from aircraft and hose lines, as well as handlines dug by L.A. County crews, to attack the fire, according to the complaint. Firefighters continued suppression efforts during the day on Jan. 1, wetting down areas within the fire perimeter. When the suppression efforts were over, the affidavit said, the fire crews left fire hoses on site, in case they needed to be redeployed.

Jan. 2:LAFD personnel returned to the scene to collect the fire hoses. According to the affidavit, it appeared to them that the fire was fully extinguished.

But investigators determined that during the Lachman fire, a firebrand became seated within the dense vegetation, continuing to smolder and burn within the roots underground. Strong winds brought the embers to the surface, to grow into a deadly conflagration.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

Link to Image

Pacific Palisades, CA - January 07: Firefighters battle a house fire off Bollinger Drive in Pacific Palisades, CA after a brush fire, called the Palisades fire, quickly consumed more than 200 acres of vegetation today and was believed to have damaged multiple homes as the flames were pushed by gusting Santa Ana winds on Tuesday, Jan. 7, 2025. (Wally Skalij / Los Angeles Times)

Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88C3-RX18-S02R-00000-00Mañueco: "What has happened is too important to make political calculations": "What has happened is too important to make political calculations".2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisMañueco: "What has happened is too important to make political calculations": "What has happened is too important to make political calculations".


EL PAÍS offers free of charge the latest news about the fires. If you want to support our journalism, subscribe.
The president of Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, has affirmed that the wave of fires that has devastated the northwest of his community has been "too important to make political calculations", despite the fact that he himself has joined his party's criticism of the Government for what they consider to be its insufficient support. Mañueco appeared in the regional Parliament to explain the management carried out by his government of the fires that are still burning in his community. In the community there are still four active fires of maximum risk level, and another five of level 1, although the situation has improved thanks to the weather. Finally, after several days out of control, firefighters have made progress in fighting the fire in Fasgar (León). It has also improved in Galicia, which has dawned with all its fires, at least, stabilized. In Asturias, only the Ibias fire is not under control. During the early morning, the Junta de Andalucía has declared level 1 emergency for a fire in Lubrín (Almería), which has forced to evacuate several people. The King and Queen of Spain visit the area of Extremadura affected by the fires.


Go to topNew publicationsEl País
Castilla y León : Mañueco puts the number of fires that affected his community during the first 23 days of August at 348.
The president of the Junta de Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernandez Mañueco, has assured that during the first 23 days of August, his community was affected by 348 fires and has thanked "very especially the firefighting operation of Castilla y León".
Mañueco thanked the local, provincial and regional institutions, as well as the Government of Spain, for the resources and assistance provided during this wave of fires, although during the critical moments and with the operation itself overwhelmed, he criticized the central Executive for not supplying the means that he demanded despite the fact that he obtained unused state support... He also valued the "fire fighting operation of Castilla y León".
The senior official has pointed to "exceptional weather conditions and an unusual heat wave with strong winds and low humidity" to justify the multitude of fires suffered in the territory and recalled that the flames have also affected other territories or European countries.
Published at: 11:20 CEST 29/08/2025 and modified at 11:20 CEST 29/08/2025 Juan Navarro
Mañueco: "What is happening is too important and too real to make political calculations".
The president of the Junta de Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, has begun his statement by lamenting the personal and material damage in the fires that have ravaged the region: "Our land has been hit by a tragedy that has reaped lives, razed land and villages, reduced homes to ashes and snatched hope from many families. The true tribute to those who have lost everything is to raise this debate to the level of the dignity of our people, away from simplism and electoral calculation".
The president has assured that he wants a debate away from politics: "What is happening is too important and too real to make political calculations". Mañueco added that he would have preferred to appear in the Cortes once the wave of fires had ended.
Published at: 11:14 CEST 29/08/2025 and modified at 11:17 CEST 29/08/2025 El País
The fire is out of control for several days, but the fire is still burning in Fasgar.
The night work, with backfires, have allowed progress in the work of extinguishing the fire Fasgar, technically linked to Igüeña, and according to the Junta de Castilla y León, is getting to stop it after several days out of control by wind effect.
After 21 days of fighting the flames, the Junta has indicated in a message through social networks that the technical fire has managed to close tonight its advance towards the valley of the Omaña river, and although "there are small columns of smoke, the clouds can be seen at the top", although there is still work ahead.
Thus, the situation seems to be improving in the Fasgar fire, which yesterday was the one that presented the most unfavorable evolution in all Spain, for being aggressive and unpredictable, and the town of Espina de Tremor, towards which it was heading, seems to be free of danger, as well as Tremor de Arriba.
Thus, with no evacuated localities in El Bierzo at the moment, work continues with intensity in the area in order to take advantage of the weather conditions. A humidity of 80% and the drop in temperatures, in addition to the forecast of rain, could give a turn to a fire that has put in check Colinas del Campo and continues to burn at altitudes above 2,000 meters, with headwinds. (EFE)
Published at: 11:04 CEST 29/08/2025 El País
Valencia : The forest fire declared in Orihuela (Alicante) remains active after several reactivations
The forest fire that broke out Thursday morning in the hamlet of La Aparecida, in the municipality of the Alicante town of Orihuela, remains active this Friday after registering several reproductions, as reported by the Provincial Consortium of Firefighters of Alicante.
This agency has indicated that although the fire was initially expected to be extinguished at 7.00 this Friday, several reproductions recorded during the night, controlled by the forest firefighters assigned to the area, have delayed the declaration of extinction.
The fire was brought under control by the Provincial Consortium of Firefighters of Alicante at 19.10 hours on Thursday. However, the means displaced to the area remained to continue the work to extinguish it.
The notice of the fire was received at 12.59 hours on Thursday, after some dry bushes began to burn near a mountain and the fire spread rapidly to a forest area. After affecting a hillside, it spread to an area of pine trees. (EP)

Posted at: 10:54 CEST 29/08/2025 Juan Navarro
Castilla y León | Dozens of people protest in front of the Parliament against the management of Mañueco
Several dozens of people have concentrated this Friday in front of the Cortes de Castilla y León in advance of the extraordinary appearance of the president, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco (PP), to report on the operation of fires in this August crisis. Among them are several forest firefighters who lead the chants against Mañueco and his Minister of Environment, Juan Carlos Suárez-Quiñones, whom they call for resignation. They also cry out about their unstable working conditions while waving their batfuegos.
Published at: 10:18 CEST 29/08/2025 and modified at: 10:21 CEST 29/08/2025 El País
Luis Planas, in the Senate: "If the PP summons us so soon, it is a sign of confidence in the Government".
The Minister of Agriculture, Luis Planas, has ironized with the haste with which he has been summoned to the Senate by the PP to account for the management of fires as far as his department is concerned. "I believe that if we have been summoned so soon by the Popular Party, it is a sign of confidence in the Government, of confidence in what we have done since June 2018," he said in his initial intervention in the Agriculture Committee.
In this sense, he has stated that it still seems to him "hasty to take stock" of the damage caused by the fires "at this time". Planas has argued that "only when they are extinguished" will be able to "make an accurate and rigorous assessment" of the damage and "give a response that is appropriate". He also explained that he was "surprised" when he received the request to appear in the commission "because it is still a necessary moment of work and priority to extinguish the fires".
Planas has shown "admiration and respect" for those who are working in extinguishing the fires and has expressed his "solidarity and support to all the families and friends of the victims, the injured and the members of the Military Emergency Unit, injured this week and who are convalescing". He also wanted to send a message of support to the rest of the injured and affected, "to all those affected in our rural world, particularly our farmers and ranchers".
Published at: 10:04 CEST 29/08/2025 and modified at: 10:11 CEST 29/08/2025 El País
The fire in Lubrín (Almería) could have been caused by a power line.
The forest fire declared last night in the place of Las Cubillas, in Lubrín (Almería), which has forced to activate the emergency phase 1 of Plan Infoca and the preventive eviction of about twenty residents in the municipality of Bédar, may have originated from a fault in a power line, according to municipal sources.
The fire started after 23.00, when the single emergency telephone 112 of Andalusia began receiving calls from individuals who alerted of the presence of a fire in the area of Barranco Muñoz, in Lubrín. Immediately mobilized the Civil Guard, Fire Department, Local Police and Infoca troops, who moved terrestrial means to the site. At dawn support aircraft have been added.
The mayor of Lubrín, Domingo Ramos (PSOE), explained that in the town center of the town there have been no incidents, although it has lived "a night in suspense" in the neighborhoods of El Marchal and Campico de las Moletas, where the flames approached. "In the core of Lubrín there is no problem. In the Alcarria is more or less controlled, which is where the fire started, in the place of Barranco Muñoz. But in the area of the two cores right now are the media trying to extinguish the fire, "he said.
On the causes, Ramos has indicated that several neighbors point to a power line as a possible origin. "They have seen that it was sparking and possibly has been the reason for the fire," he said.
The alderman has recalled that the municipality has a group of rapid assistance that usually arrives in just five or ten minutes to the outbreaks and has managed to quell small fires on other occasions, although in this case it was impossible. "It was terrible, at night and in an area with huge vegetation," he added.
The mayor of Lubrín has stressed that this is the third fire suffered by the municipality so far this summer and has described the summer campaign as "very complicated".
The fire also forced to act in the neighboring municipality of Bédar. Its mayor, Angel Collado (PSOE), explained that everything pointed to the flames would enter the municipality, which led to order the eviction of two small neighborhoods, with about 20 people in total. "Finally, the wind stopped and has not affected us. This morning, first thing, we have told the neighbors that they could return to their homes," he said. Collado has admitted that the population lived moments of tension during the night, which have reminded the great fire of 2012. "We had a difficult time, even though everything pointed to the fact that it was not going to affect us," he said.(EFE)
Published at: 09:51 CEST 29/08/2025 and modified at 09:51 CEST 29/08/2025 El Pais
The Minister of Agriculture appears in the Senate
The Minister of Agriculture, Luis Planas, appears at this time in the Senate to account for the management of fires as it concerns his department. Many farmers and ranchers have suffered losses and damage to their farms by fires that have ravaged the northwest of Spain, so they claim official aid.
Published at: 09:37 CEST 29/08/2025 and modified at: 09:52 CEST 29/08/2025 El País
Andalusia | Activated emergency phase 1 for a forest fire in Lubrín (Almería)
The Andalusian government has raised to the emergency phase, operational situation 1, the Infoca Plan in the province of Almeria by a forest fire declared last night in the place of Las Cubillas, in the municipality of Lubrín (Almería).
According to a note from the emergency service 112, the Minister of the Presidency, Interior, Social Dialogue and Administrative Simplification, Antonio Sanz, has taken the decision at 5.46 this Friday in view of the evolution of the fire, which began about 23.00 on Thursday.
The measure has involved the preventive eviction of five people from the areas of Los Albaricos and Fuente de los Albaricos, in the neighboring town of Bédar (Almería).
The operation involves 11 groups of Infoca specialists, five vehicles and five technicians, in addition to the Mobile Unit of Meteorology and Transmissions, awaiting the incorporation of the aerial means with the arrival of daylight. (EFE)
Published at: 08:31 CEST 29/08/2025 and modified at 09:32 CEST 29/08/2025
Good morning. We start the narration of the last hour of the fires that have affected in this month of August to the northwest peninsular. In the early hours of this Friday, four fires of maximum risk level are still active in Castilla y León (Porto, in Zamora, and Fasgar, La Baña and Colinas del Campo de Martín Moro Toledano, in León). Thursday was a favorable day in the fight against the fire, although the reactivations are still worrying, especially in Fasgar. In Galicia, all fires were, at least, stabilized. In Asturias, likewise, only the one in Ibias remains active.
On the other hand, this Friday will appear in the Parliament of Castilla y León its president, the popular Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, much criticized for his management of the fires. The Kings, meanwhile, visit Extremadura, another of the communities affected by the wave of fires.

urn:contentItem:6FVT-1933-RSCD-825S-00000-00Studies from New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology Provide New Data on Electronics (Hierarchical Early Wireless Forest Fire Prediction System Utilizing Virtual Sensors)2025-05-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisENGINEERING - ELECTRONICSStudies from New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology Provide New Data on Electronics (Hierarchical Early Wireless Forest Fire Prediction System Utilizing Virtual Sensors)


2025 MAY 21 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Telecommunications Daily -- New research on Engineering - Electronics is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Socorro, New Mexico, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Deploying thousands of sensors across remote and challenging environments-such as the Amazon rainforest, Californian wilderness, or Australian bushlands-is a critical yet complex task for forest fire monitoring, while our backyard emulation confirmed the feasibility of small-scale deployment as a proof of concept, large-scale scenarios demand a scalable, efficient, and fault-tolerant network design. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Wireless Sensor Network (HWSN) deployment strategy with adaptive head node selection to maximize area coverage and energy efficiency."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, "The network architecture follows a three-level hierarchy as follows: The first level incorporates cells of individual sensor nodes that connect to dynamically assigned cell heads. The second level involves the aggregated clusters of such cell heads, each with an assigned cluster head. Finally, dividing all cluster heads into regions, each with a region head, directly reports all the collected information from the forest floor to a central control sink room for decision making analysis. Unlike traditional centralized or uniformly distributed models, our adaptive approach leverages a greedy coverage maximization algorithm to dynamically select head nodes that contribute to the best forest sensed data coverage at each level. Through extensive simulations, the adaptive model achieved over 96.26% coverage, using significantly fewer nodes, while reducing node transmission distances and energy consumption."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This facilitates the real-world deployment of our HWSN model in large-scale, remote forest regions, with very promising performance."
For more information on this research see: Hierarchical Early Wireless Forest Fire Prediction System Utilizing Virtual Sensors. Electronics, 2025;14(8):1634. Electronics can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Ahshanul Haque, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, Dept. of Computer Sciences, Socorro, NM 87801, United States.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/electronics14081634. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Socorro, New Mexico, United States, North and Central America, Electronics, Engineering, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2DH3-RRWT-K2VT-00000-00The King will receive this Tuesday a representation of the personnel involved in the aerial device of the fires.2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisThe King will receive this Tuesday a representation of the personnel involved in the aerial device of the fires.


King Felipe VI will receive this Tuesday, September 9, a representation of the personnel involved in the aerial device that has participated in the extinction of forest fires that have affected much of the country this summer.


The audience will be this Tuesday at 12.00 hours in the Zarzuela Palace, according to the agenda of the Royal House, collected by Europa Press.
The King visited last week areas affected by the fires in Castilla y León, Galicia and Extremadura, where he expressed having felt the "satisfaction of being able to be close to all the people" who have suffered closely the fires, and encouraged citizens to resume the canceled trips because those affected "require the affection of all".
Forest fires have burned a total of 336,345 hectares throughout Spain during the month of August, according to data from the European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus as of August 31.
By autonomous community, the largest area affected was in Galicia, with 143,628 hectares, 43%; Castilla y León, 141,264 hectares, 42%; Extremadura, 41,525 hectares, 12%. These three communities account for 97% of the area affected in August. The remaining 10,000 hectares are distributed in the rest of the autonomous communities that have had some fire episode during August.
Of this figure, 325,000 hectares correspond to large forest fires, fires of more than 500 hectares, which means that 97% of the area affected was precisely due to these large forest fires. The forested area affected is 128,350 hectares, almost 40% of the area affected by the fires.
In the case of the Natura 2000 Network, the area burned by forest fires amounted to 146,190 hectares, i.e. 43% of the area burned.
Critical areas have also been affected for the survival of more than 350 species in danger of extinction, vulnerable or in some protection regime according to the LESPRE list, species such as the urugallo, species such as the brown bear, the lynx or the black stork.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-823C-00000-00Night of evacuations in Galicia: fires in Oia, Vilaboa and Carballedo force evacuation of 100 people2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisNight of evacuations in Galicia: fires in Oia, Vilaboa and Carballedo force evacuation of 100 people


The wave of fires that has been raging in Galicia for two weeks now gives no respite. Last night new outbreaks have forced to evict more than a hundred people in the Pontevedra municipalities of Oia and Vilaboa and in the Lugo of Carballedo.


Thus, in the province of Pontevedra, was already activated during the afternoon of Thursday Situation 2 by the proximity of forest fires to the population centers of Mougas (Oia) and Vilar (Santa Cristina de Cobres, Vilaboa).
In the case of Oia, the measures taken by the firefighting troops were successfully completed, so we proceeded to the deactivation of Situation 2. With this, the 45 people evicted preventively who were in the camping Mougas and could return to the facilities. However, some of them have stayed at the Santa Tecla campsite, in A Guarda.
On the other hand, in Vilaboa, 14 people were evicted in the core of Paradellas.
In the province of Lugo, Situation 2 was activated in Carballedo due to the proximity of a forest fire to the population center of Oleiros. Thus, and also as a preventive measure, the Os Peares shelter was evacuated. A total of 53 children and 11 monitors were transferred to the Lug2 youth hostel.
In Ourense no new confinements or evacuations have been recorded and all main roads remain operational.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-82KT-00000-00Copernicus estimates the number of hectares burned in 2025 in Spain at 403,701, most of them in August2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisCopernicus estimates the number of hectares burned in 2025 in Spain at 403,701, most of them in August


The European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus has increased to 403,171 its estimate of the number of hectares burned in 2025 in Spain, according to figures consulted by Europa Press. The vast majority of these hectares have been burned in August.


The number of hectares burned was 41,903 as of July 29. By August 7 they had already reached 47,302. Subsequently, the area burned began to shoot up to 396,791, so that in the last 15 days have burned about 360,000.
If these estimates are confirmed, 2025 could be the year with more hectares burned in the XXI century, as noted in statements to Europa Press WWF based on data from the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge (MITECO). To find a year with worse figures of hectares burned would have to go back to 1994, when 437,602.50 hectares burned.
For the moment, the third vice-president and minister for Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagesen, has put the number of hectares burned up to August 10 at 138,000, although she has warned that the data will foreseeably get worse since these numbers do not include the area burned by the fires that are currently active in a large part of Spain.

urn:contentItem:6GKP-8RD3-RTX7-M2XC-00000-00Indonesia: West Papua drafts plan to use GCF Result-Based Payment funds2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSIndonesia: West Papua drafts plan to use GCF Result-Based Payment funds

The West Papua provincial government is finalizing a concept note on the use of Result-Based Payment (RBP) grant funds for climate change programs from the Green Climate Fund (GCF).

Head of the West Papua Forestry Service, Jimmy Walter Susanto, said on Monday that once completed, the activity proposal will be submitted to the Environmental Fund Management Agency (BPDLH).

He explained that the draft concept must cover seven types of activities to be implemented by the appointed intermediary institution, the Samdhana Institute. These include strengthening forest management units, the climate village program, forest and land rehabilitation, sustainable forest management, and forest fire prevention and management.

"In addition, we will develop a design for Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) related to carbon," Susanto said.

The draft also incorporates the strategic and annual work plans of the West Papua Forestry Service and the Environment and Land Service (DLHP) to avoid duplication of activities already funded by the province's 2025 regional budget (APBD).

"This ensures that activities not included in the APBD can instead be financed through the RBP grant," he explained.

Susanto underlined that the distribution of the climate grant will not pass through regional coffers but will directly fund activities carried out by the Samdhana Institute.

All proposed programs have received approval from the BPDLH, while Samdhana's appointment as implementing partner reflects its proven track record.

"Samdhana Institute has conducted conservation work in Teluk Bintuni District and several other areas in Papua," he said, adding that the organization also presented its activities to West Papua Governor Dominggus Mandacan on August 13.

Source: ANTARA News

urn:contentItem:6GM2-96F3-RSY7-J21N-00000-00WWII bombs and tanks explode during fire in England; watch videos2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:36ZLexisNexisWWII bombs and tanks explode during fire in England; watch videos


The already risky work of the firefighters battling the forest fire on the North York Moors in England has been made even more dangerous by the presence of bombs and shells from World War II tanks buried under the dry vegetation. According to the county's chief fire officer, Jonathan Dyson, there were almost 20 explosions as the fire burned through the vegetation, detonating hidden antique weapons.





The fire, which started on August 11, has affected around 25 square kilometers in the picturesque coastal region of North Yorkshire, according to the American newspaper CBS News. Teams of firefighters, farmers and rangers are working with water tanks, tractors and firebreaks to try to contain the blaze and protect nearby areas, including farms and sheep pastures.
Part of the affected area had been a tank training camp in the 1940s, which explains the presence of the ammunition. Nearby, the RAF Fylingdales radar station is still in operation.

Take a look:

The British Ministry of Defense confirmed that an explosives deactivation team found "several items of unexploded munitions from the Second World War", classifying them as "inert projectiles for practice". Faced with the risk, firefighters adopted a defensive strategy to protect their teams.
The scale of the fire is unusual for the north of England, traditionally marked by frequent rainfall. This year, however, an exceptionally hot and dry spring and early summer left the moors completely parched.
The North York Moors National Park, which covers more than 1,480 km² of rolling hills, includes coastal villages and towns such as Whitby, a popular tourist destination. The fire has forced the closure of roads, campsites and businesses.
